question_text: How does pyrolysis temperature affect the yield and composition of tyre pyrolysis oil (TPO), and what are the underlying chemical mechanisms driving these changes?
standard_answer: Pyrolysis temperature critically influences TPO yield through competing decomposition and cracking mechanisms. At lower temperatures (300-400°C), primary pyrolysis dominates, breaking weaker bonds in rubber polymers like natural rubber (NR) and styrene-butadiene rubber (SBR) to produce volatile hydrocarbons, maximizing liquid yield. As temperature increases to 500-600°C, secondary cracking becomes significant: longer hydrocarbon chains crack into lighter fractions, increasing gas yield at the expense of TPO. Specifically, alkenes and cycloalkenes formed during initial decomposition undergo Diels-Alder reactions and aromatization, converting to benzene derivatives and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Above 600°C, extensive cracking reduces TPO yield further while increasing gas production and PAH content due to enhanced ring-opening and recyclization reactions. The optimal TPO yield typically peaks around 500°C, balancing primary decomposition and minimizing secondary cracking.
